Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Reasearch: Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric structure, and Precipitation at Summit (ICECAPS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2010, the observatory at Summit, Greenland, in the center of the Greenland Ice Sheet (GIS), was expanded to include a comprehensive suite of cloud-atmosphere observing instruments including microwave and infrared spectrometers, cloud radar, depolarization lidar, ceilometer, precipitation sensor, sodar, and a twice-daily radiosonde program. This observing effort was termed ICECAPS (Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric state, and Precipitation at Summit). A continuation of this project is proposed here, with moderate enhancements to include atmospheric aerosol observations. Measurements from this expanded instrument suite will be used to derive critical baseline atmospheric data products including:
* Atmospheric State - tropospheric temperature, moisture, and wind profiles
* Aerosols - concentration of total particles and cloud condensation nuclei
* Cloud Macrophysics - occurrence, vertical boundaries, temperature
* Cloud Microphysics - phase, water content, and characteristic particle size
* Precipitation - type and rate
Together these products, when combined with similar ongoing measurements at Summit, can be used to study processes that impact the surface energy budget and precipitation at the site, as well as addressing questions related to atmospheric stability, cloud phase composition, the persistence of stratiform clouds, and aerosol-cloud interactions. It is further anticipated that these observations will continue to be used by a broad cross-section of the scientific community to promote understanding of GIS and Arctic climate, validate satellite observations, and evaluate model simulations. Graduate students play significant roles in most aspects of this project, gaining valuable experience with polar field work, operating instruments, and processing data. In addition, this research team has developed a unique education and outreach plan to work with students from local schools using simple, proxy instrumentation to help develop their understanding of atmospheric principles and observations, and to enhance the scientific curriculum in their schools via a wide range of outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric state, and Precipitation at Summit (ICECAPS) project includes operation of a suite of atmospheric instruments that have continuously observed clouds, precipitation, atmospheric structure, and radiation over Summit, Greenland since 2010. This first-of-its-kind deployment has provided many ground-breaking observations that have contributed to a wealth of scientific research, instrument and technique development, operational support, education, and personnel development.

Scientifically, ICECAPS has provided many new insights into atmospheric processes that impact the surface energy and precipitation budgets of the Greenland Ice Sheet. At the forefront is research into clouds and cloud processes. Initial results showed that, surprisingly, cloud structure and processes have many similarities to those over the rest of the Arctic, in spite of the vastly different local conditions. Sophisticated, multi-instrument studies have clarified that clouds exert a radiatively warming effect on the central ice sheet surface year round and that this radiative forcing impacts the balance of other energetic terms at the surface. Process relationships that describe how the ice sheet surface responds to clouds were developed and used in a unique and impactful way to assess how climate models represent these same processes. Extending beyond clouds, the ICECAPS measurements have provided a first detailed view of precipitation over central Greenland. Most precipitation occurs in summertime, and can come through clouds that are comprised of entirely ice or those that also contain liquid water at temperatures below the freezing point. Each of these types of cloud-precipitation states occurs during unique conditions and each has a different impact on the snowfall intensity and duration. To place all of these local cloud and precipitation processes in context, sophisticated classification techniques were used to understand how the large-scale atmospheric circulation around Greenland impacts atmospheric moisture, clouds, and radiation, and how these components all work together to ultimately control the variability of surface temperature, and often surface melt, over the ice sheet. Using all of this foundational observation-based information, high-resolution model simulations have been performed that explore the role of clouds for impacting surface melt over all of Greenland. Since 2013, University of Colorado participants in this project have produced 23 publications using ICECAPS data, and numerous other publications have resulted via collaborators and other partners.

ICECAPS has also achieved numerous broad impacts on science and society. First, data from the project has contributed to operational weather forecast models on a daily basis and has informed numerous stakeholders, such as airlines, of conditions over Greenland. The data has also been used by the European Space Agency for evaluation of their satellite measurements and by collaborators at numerous institutions that are developing new instrumentation for observing atmospheric phenomena. The project has also supported a unique outreach effort that involves hand-held instruments that emulate some of the more sophisticated observations made in the field. These instruments are the basis for working with K-12 communities on related scientific concepts. Lastly, the project has featured prominent roles for numerous students, who have been involved in field work, instrument oversight, data processing, and analysis. Graduate degrees associated with the University of Colorado portion of this project include 2 PhDs and 2 Master’s degrees, with many other students participating via collaborating institutions.
